title: Regression Discontinuity Design Application
text: rddapp provides set functions analysis regression-discontinuity design (RDD). three main parts : Estimation effects interest Power analysis Assumption checks

title: Regression Discontinuity Design Application
text: package estimates treatment effects RDDs following designs approaches: Parametric RDD single assignment variables (sharp fuzzy designs) Non-parametric RDD single assignment variables (sharp fuzzy designs) Parametric RDDs two assignment variables (sharp fuzzy designs), using univariate, centering, frontier approaches

title: Regression Discontinuity Design Application
text: Given input user desired Type error rate assumptions population, package allows estimation power following designs: Single assignment RDDs (sharp fuzzy) using parametric non-parametric estimation Multiple-assignment RDDs (sharp fuzzy) using various parametric models

title: Regression Discontinuity Design Application
text: package allows user perform variety assumption sensitivity checks, including: McCrary’s sorting test assignment variable Sensitivity chosen bandwidth non-parametric estimation Placebo tests examine treatment effects values away cut-Discontinuities treatment probability cut-Discontinuities baseline covariates

title: Regression Discontinuity Design Application
code: # Install the released version from CRAN install.packages("rddapp")  # Or the development version from GitHub: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("felixthoemmes/rddapp")

title: Attrition Checks — attr_check
text: attr_check reports missing data treatment variable, assignment variable, outcome. internal function typically directly invoked user.  can accessed using triple colon, rddapp:::attr_check().

code: attr_check(x1, y, t, x2 = NULL)

title: Attrition Checks — attr_check
text: x1 numeric object containing assignment variable. y numeric object containing outcome variable, dimensionality  x1. t numeric object containing treatment variable (coded 0 untreated 1 treated), dimensionality  x1 y. x2 numeric object containing secondary assignment variable.

title: Attrition Checks — attr_check
text: attr_check returns list containing amount percentage missing data variables subgroups, treatment.

title: Imbens-Kalyanaraman 2009 Optimal Bandwidth Calculation — bw_ik09
text: bw_ik09 calculates Imbens-Kalyanaraman (2009) optimal bandwidth local linear regression regression discontinuity designs. based IKbandwidth function "rdd" package.  internal function typically directly invoked user.  can accessed using triple colon, rddapp:::bw_ik09().

code: bw_ik09(X, Y, cutpoint = NULL, verbose = FALSE, kernel = "triangular")

title: Imbens-Kalyanaraman 2009 Optimal Bandwidth Calculation — bw_ik09
text: X numeric vector containing running variable. Y numeric vector containing outcome variable. cutpoint numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined. default 0. verbose logical value indicating whether print information terminal.  default FALSE. kernel string indicating kernel use. Options "triangular"  (default recommended), "rectangular", "epanechnikov", "quartic",  "triweight", "tricube", "cosine".

McCrary Sorting Test — dc_test
text: dc_test implements McCrary (2008) sorting test identify violations assignment rules. based DCdensity function "rdd" package.

title: McCrary Sorting Test — dc_test
code: dc_test(   runvar,   cutpoint,   bin = NULL,   bw = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   plot = TRUE,   ext.out = FALSE,   htest = FALSE,   level = 0.95,   digits = max(3, getOption("digits") - 3),   timeout = 30 )

title: McCrary Sorting Test — dc_test
text: runvar numeric vector containing running variable. cutpoint numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined. default 0. bin numeric value containing binwidth. default 2*sd(runvar)*length(runvar)^(-.5). bw numeric value containing bandwidth use. bandwidth supplied, default uses bandwidth selection calculation  McCrary (2008). verbose logical value indicating whether print diagnostic information  terminal. default TRUE. plot logical value indicating whether plot histogram density estimations  default TRUE. user may wrap function additional graphical options  modify plot. ext.logical value indicating whether return extended output.  default FALSE. FALSE dc_test return p-value test, print information.  TRUE, dc_test return print additional information documented . htest logical value indicating whether return "htest" object  compatible base R's hypothesis test output. default FALSE. level numerical value 0 1 specifying confidence level confidence intervals. default 0.95. digits non-negative integer specifying number digits display output. default max(3, getOption("digits") - 3). timeout non-negative numerical value specifying maximum number seconds  expressions function allowed run. default 30. Specify Inf run expressions completion.

title: McCrary Sorting Test — dc_test
text: ext.FALSE, dc_test returns numeric value specifying p-value McCrary (2008) sorting test.    Additional output enabled ext.TRUE.    case, dc_test returns list following elements: theta estimated log difference heights density curve cutpoint. se standard error theta. z z statistic test. p p-value test. p-value significance threshold indicates    user can reject null hypothesis sorting. binsize calculated size bins test. bw calculated bandwidth test. cutpoint cutpoint used. data dataframe binning histogram. Columns cellmp    (midpoints cell) cellval (normalized height cell).

Drew Dimmery (2016). rdd: Regression Discontinuity Estimation. R package version 0.57. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rdd

Error  lower.CL  upper.CL  z value  Pr(>|z|)    #>    0.2472    0.2011     -0.1469    0.6413    1.2294   0.2189     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Confidence interval used:  0.95  #>  #> [1] 0.2189345  # Discontinuity x <- runif(1000, -1, 1) x <- x + 2 * (runif(1000, -1, 1) > 0 & x < 0) dc_test(x, 0) #> Binwidth: #> 0.04767  #>  #> Bandwidth: #> 0.6016  #>   #> Estimate for log difference in heights: #>   Estimate  Std. Error  lower.CL  upper.CL  z value  Pr(>|z|)     #>   0.56818   0.20925     0.15806   0.97830   2.71536  0.00662   ** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Confidence interval used:  0.95  #>  #> [1] 0.006620445

title: Multivariate Frontier Regression Discontinuity Estimation — mfrd_est
text: y numeric object containing outcome variable. x1 numeric object containing first assignment variable. x2 numeric object containing second assignment variable. c1 numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined x1. c2 numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined x2. t.design character vector length 2 specifying treatment option according design. first entry x1 second entry x2. Options   "g" (treatment assigned x1 greater cutoff), "geq" (treatment assigned x1 greater equal cutoff), "l" (treatment assigned x1 less cutoff), "leq" (treatment assigned x1 less equal cutoff). options available x2. local non-negative numeric value specifying range neighboring points around cutoff  standardized scale, assignment variable. default 0.15. front.bw non-negative numeric vector length 3 specifying bandwidths estimate RD three effects models (complete model, heterogeneous treatment model, treatment model)  detailed Wong, Steiner, Cook (2013). NA, front.bw determined cross-validation. default NA. m non-negative integer specifying number uniformly--random samples draw search candidates front.bw, front.bw NA. default 10. k non-negative integer specifying number folds cross-validation determine front.bw, front.bw NA. default 5. kernel string indicating kernel use. Options "triangular"  (default recommended), "rectangular", "epanechnikov", "quartic",  "triweight", "tricube", "cosine". ngrid non-negative integer specifying number non-zero grid points assignment variable, also number zero grid points assignment variable. default 250. value used  Wong, Steiner Cook (2013) 2500, may cause long computational time. margin non-negative numeric value specifying range grid points beyond minimum maximum sample points assignment variable. grid used impute potential outcomes along frontier, Wong, Steiner, Cook (2013). default 0.03. boot optional non-negative integer specifying number bootstrap samples obtain standard error estimates. cluster optional vector length n specifying clusters within errors assumed correlated. result reporting cluster robust SEs. suggested data discrete running  variable clustered unique value running variable (Lee Card, 2008). stop..error logical value indicating whether remove bootstraps cause error integrate function. TRUE, bootstraps cause error removed resampled specified number  bootstrap samples acquired. FALSE, bootstraps cause error removed. default TRUE.

Estimates suffix "ev1" "ev2" correspond expected values frontier, given model. bandwidth .... m_s list containing estimates complete model, parametric non-parametric (optimal, half, double bandwidth) cases. list  coefficient estimates, residuals, effects, weights (non-parametric zcx2),  treatment indicators overall treatment (tr) based treatment assignment x1 (tr1), x2 (tr2), assignment variables (trb). obs List number observations used model. impute logical value indicating Multivariate Regression Discontinuity Estimation — mrd_est
text: mrd_est estimates treatment effects multivariate regression discontinuity design (MRDD) two assignment variables,  including frontier average treatment effect (tau_MRD)  frontier-specific effects (tau_R tau_M) simultaneously.

title: Multivariate Regression Discontinuity Estimation — mrd_est
code: mrd_est(   formula,   data,   subset = NULL,   cutpoint = NULL,   bw = NULL,   front.bw = NA,   m = 10,   k = 5,   kernel = "triangular",   se.type = "HC1",   cluster = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   less = FALSE,   est.cov = FALSE,   est.itt = FALSE,   local = 0.15,   ngrid = 250,   margin = 0.03,   boot = NULL,   method = c("center", "univ", "front"),   t.design = NULL,   stop.on.error = TRUE )

Possible values "IK09", "IK12", user-specified non-negative numeric vector containing bandwidths estimate RD. default "IK12". bw "IK12", bandwidth calculated using Imbens-Kalyanaraman  2012 method. bw  "IK09", bandwidth calculated using  Imbens-Kalyanaraman 2009 method. , RD estimated bandwidth, half bandwidth, twice bandwidth.  single value passed function, RD similarly estimated bandwidth, half bandwidth,  twice bandwidth. front.bw non-negative numeric vector length 3 specifying bandwidths estimate RD three effects models (complete model, heterogeneous treatment model, treatment model)  detailed Wong, Steiner, Cook (2013). NA, front.bw determined cross-validation. default NA. m non-negative integer specifying number uniformly--random samples draw search candidates front.bw, front.bw NA. default 10. k non-negative integer specifying number folds cross-validation determine front.bw, front.bw NA. default 5. kernel string indicating kernel use. Options "triangular"  (default recommended), "rectangular", "epanechnikov", "quartic",  "triweight", "tricube", "cosine". se.type specifies robust standard error calculation method use, "sandwich" package. Options , vcovHC, "HC3", "const", "HC", "HC0",  "HC1", "HC2", "HC4", "HC4m", "HC5". default "HC1". option overridden cluster. cluster optional vector length n specifying clusters within errors assumed correlated. result reporting cluster robust SEs. option overrides anything specified se.type. suggested data discrete running  variable clustered unique value running variable (Lee Card, 2008). verbose logical value indicating whether print additional information  terminal, including results instrumental variable regression, outputs background regression models. default FALSE. less Logical. title: Multivariate Regression Discontinuity Estimation — mrd_est
text: mrd_est returns object class "mrd".   function summary used obtain print summary    estimated regression discontinuity. object class mrd list    containing following components estimated treatment effect, tau_MRD tau_R tau_M: type string denoting either "sharp" "fuzzy" RDD. call matched call. est Numeric vector estimate discontinuity outcome    sharp MRDD Wald estimator fuzzy MRDD, corresponding bandwidth, applicable. se Numeric vector standard error corresponding bandwidth, applicable. ci matrix 95   corresponding bandwidth, applicable. bw Numeric vector bandwidth used estimation. z Numeric vector z statistic corresponding bandwidth, applicable. p Numeric vector p-value corresponding bandwidth, applicable. obs Vector number observations within corresponding bandwidth, applicable. cov names covariates. model sharp design, list lm objects returned.   fuzzy design, list lists returned, two elements:    firststage, first stage lm object, iv, ivreg object.    model returned parametric non-parametric case corresponding bandwidth. frame Returns model frame used fitting. na.action observations removed fitting due missingness. impute logical value indicating whether multiple imputation used . d Numeric vector effect size (Cohen's d) estimate.

title: Multivariate Regression Discontinuity Estimation — mrd_est
code: set.seed(12345) x1 <- runif(1000, -1, 1) x2 <- runif(1000, -1, 1) cov <- rnorm(1000) y <- 3 + 2 * (x1 >= 0) + 3 * cov + 10 * (x2 >= 0) + rnorm(1000) # centering mrd_est(y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, method = "center", t.design = c("geq", "geq")) #> $center #> $center$tau_MRD #>  #> Call: #> rd_est(formula = Y ~ X | cov, data = data, subset = NULL, cutpoint = 0,  #>     bw = NULL, kernel = "triangular", se.type = "HC1", cluster = cluster,  #>     verbose = FALSE, less = FALSE, est.cov = FALSE, est.itt = FALSE,  #>     t.design = "leq") #>  #> Coefficients: #>     Linear   Quadratic       Cubic         Opt    Half-Opt  Double-Opt   #>      6.531       6.592       6.830       6.674       6.554       6.545   #>  #>  #>  #> $call #> mrd_est(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, method = "center", t.design = c("geq",  #>     "geq")) #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "mrd" # univariate mrd_est(y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, method = "univ", t.design = c("geq", "geq")) #> $univ #> $univ$tau_R #>  #> Call: #> rd_est(formula = Y ~ X1 | cov, data = data, subset = subset1,  #>     cutpoint = 0, bw = NULL, kernel = "triangular", se.type = "HC1",  #>     cluster = cluster, verbose = FALSE, less = FALSE, est.cov = FALSE,  #>     est.itt = FALSE, t.design = "geq") #>  #> Coefficients: #>     Linear   Quadratic       Cubic         Opt    Half-Opt  Double-Opt   #>      2.367       2.421       2.725       2.404       2.601       2.375   #>  #>  #> $univ$tau_M #>  #> Call: #> rd_est(formula = Y ~ X2 | cov, data = data, subset = subset2,  #>     cutpoint = 0, bw = NULL, kernel = "triangular", se.type = "HC1",  #>     cluster = cluster, verbose = FALSE, less = FALSE, est.cov = FALSE,  #>     est.itt = FALSE, t.design = "geq") #>  #> Coefficients: #>     Linear   Quadratic       Cubic         Opt    Half-Opt  Double-Opt   #>     10.154       9.939      10.098      10.033       9.959      10.106   #>  #>  #>  #> $call #> mrd_est(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, method = "univ", t.design = c("geq",  #>     "geq")) #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "mrd" # frontier mrd_est(y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, method = "front", t.design = c("geq", "geq")) #> $front #> $front$tau_MRD #>  #> Call: #> mfrd_est(y = Y, x1 = X1, x2 = X2, c1 = 0, c2 = 0, t.design = c("geq",  #> "geq"), local = 0.15, front.bw = NA, m = 10, k = 5, kernel = "triangular",  #>     ngrid = 250, margin = 0.03, boot = NULL, cluster = NULL,  #>     stop.on.error = TRUE) #>  #> Coefficients: #>            ev1     ev2     ate     htev1   htev2   htate   tev1    tev2   #> Param       2.062   9.903   6.442   2.375  10.486   6.906   4.563   4.563 #> bw          1.979   9.574   6.221   2.257  10.294   6.746   5.930   5.930 #> Half-bw     1.712   8.876   5.714   2.066  10.013   6.505   5.803   5.803 #> Double-bw   2.038   9.765   6.354   2.324  10.400   6.835   5.508   5.508 #>            tate   #> Param       4.563 #> bw          5.930 #> Half-bw     5.803 #> Double-bw   5.508 #>  #>  #>  #> $call #> mrd_est(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, method = "front", t.design = c("geq",  #>     "geq")) #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "mrd"

RD estimated bandwidth, half bandwidth, twice bandwidth.  single value passed function, RD similarly estimated bandwidth, half bandwidth,  twice bandwidth. front.bw non-negative numeric vector length 3 specifying bandwidths estimate RD three effects models (complete model, heterogeneous treatment model, treatment model)  detailed Wong, Steiner, Cook (2013). NA, front.bw determined cross-validation. default NA. m non-negative integer specifying number uniformly--random samples draw search candidates front.bw, front.bw NA. default 10. k non-negative integer specifying number folds cross-validation determine front.bw, front.bw NA. default 5. kernel string indicating kernel use. Options "triangular"  (default recommended), "rectangular", "epanechnikov", "quartic",  "triweight", "tricube", "cosine". se.type specifies robust standard error calculation method use, "sandwich" package. Options , vcovHC, "HC3", "const", "HC", "HC0",  "HC1", "HC2", "HC4", "HC4m", "HC5". default "HC1". option overridden cluster. cluster optional vector length n specifying clusters within errors assumed correlated. result reporting cluster robust SEs. option overrides anything specified se.type. suggested data discrete running  variable clustered unique value running variable (Lee Card, 2008). impute optional vector length n containing grouping variable  specifies imputed variables missing values. verbose logical value indicating whether print additional information  terminal. default FALSE. less Logical. TRUE, return estimates parametric linear optimal bandwidth non-parametric models . FALSE  return estimates linear, quadratic, cubic parametric models  optimal, half double bandwidths non-parametric models. default FALSE. est.cov Logical. TRUE, estimates covariates included. FALSE, estimates covariates included. default FALSE. option applicable method "front". est.itt Logical. TRUE, estimates intent--treat (ITT) returned. FALSE, estimates ITT returned. default FALSE. option applicable method "front". local non-negative numeric value specifying range neighboring points around cutoff  standardized scale, assignment variable. default 0.15. ngrid non-negative integer specifying number non-zero grid points assignment variable, also number zero grid points assignment variable. default 250. value used  Wong, Steiner Cook (2013) 2500, may cause long computational time. margin non-negative numeric value specifying range grid points beyond minimum maximum sample points assignment variable. default 0.03. boot optional non-negative integer specifying number bootstrap samples obtain standard error estimates. arugment optional method "front". method string specifying method estimate RD effect. Options "center",  "univ", "front", based centering, univariate, frontier approaches (respectively) Wong, Steiner, Cook (2013). t.design character vector length 2 specifying treatment option according design. first entry x1 second entry x2. Options   "g" (treatment assigned x1 greater cutoff), "geq" (treatment assigned x1 greater equal cutoff), "l" (treatment assigned x1 less cutoff), "leq" (treatment assigned x1 less equal cutoff). options available x2. stop..error logical value indicating whether remove bootstraps cause error integrate function. TRUE, bootstraps cause error removed resampled specified number  bootstrap samples acquired. FALSE, bootstraps cause error removed. default TRUE.

title: Multiple Imputation of Multivariate Regression Discontinuity Estimation — mrd_impute
code: set.seed(12345) x1 <- runif(300, -1, 1) x2 <- runif(300, -1, 1) cov <- rnorm(300) y <- 3 + 2 * (x1 >= 0) + 3 * cov + 10 * (x2 >= 0) + rnorm(300) imp <- rep(1:3, each = 100) # all examples below have smaller numbers of m to keep run-time low # centering mrd_impute(y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, impute = imp, method = "center", t.design = c("geq", "geq"), m = 3) #> $call #> mrd_impute(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, m = 3, impute = imp,  #>     method = "center", t.design = c("geq", "geq")) #>  #> $center #> $center$tau_MRD #>  #> Call: #> rd_est(formula = Y ~ X | cov, data = data, subset = NULL, cutpoint = 0,  #>     bw = NULL, kernel = "triangular", se.type = "HC1", cluster = cluster,  #>     verbose = FALSE, less = FALSE, est.cov = FALSE, est.itt = FALSE,  #>     t.design = "leq") #>  #> Coefficients: #>     Linear   Quadratic       Cubic         Opt    Half-Opt  Double-Opt   #>      6.679       5.056       6.532       6.534       6.126       6.348   #>  #>  #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "mrd" # univariate mrd_impute(y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, impute = imp, method = "univ", t.design = c("geq", "geq"), m = 3) #> $call #> mrd_impute(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, m = 3, impute = imp,  #>     method = "univ", t.design = c("geq", "geq")) #>  #> $univ #> $univ$tau_R #>  #> Call: #> rd_est(formula = Y ~ X1 | cov, data = data, subset = subset1,  #>     cutpoint = 0, bw = NULL, kernel = "triangular", se.type = "HC1",  #>     cluster = cluster, verbose = FALSE, less = FALSE, est.cov = FALSE,  #>     est.itt = FALSE, t.design = "geq") #>  #> Coefficients: #>     Linear   Quadratic       Cubic         Opt    Half-Opt  Double-Opt   #>      1.792       1.844       1.619       1.864       1.844       1.796   #>  #>  #> $univ$tau_M #>  #> Call: #> rd_est(formula = Y ~ X2 | cov, data = data, subset = subset2,  #>     cutpoint = 0, bw = NULL, kernel = "triangular", se.type = "HC1",  #>     cluster = cluster, verbose = FALSE, less = FALSE, est.cov = FALSE,  #>     est.itt = FALSE, t.design = "geq") #>  #> Coefficients: #>     Linear   Quadratic       Cubic         Opt    Half-Opt  Double-Opt   #>      9.326      10.113      11.082      10.037      10.237       9.521   #>  #>  #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "mrd" # frontier - don't run due to computation time if (FALSE) mrd_impute(y ~ x1 + x2 | cov, impute = imp, method = "front",                     boot = 1000, t.design = c("geq", "geq"), m = 3)

title: Power Analysis of Multivariate Regression Discontinuity — mrd_power
text: num.rep non-negative integer specifying number repetitions used calculate empirical power. default 100. sample.size non-negative integer specifying number observations sample. default 100. x1.dist string specifying distribution first assignment variable, x1. Options "normal"  "uniform". default "normal" distribution. x1.para numeric vector length 2 specifying parameters distribution first assignment variable, x1. x1.dist "normal", x1.para includes mean standard deviation normal distribution. x1.dist "uniform", x1.para includes  upper lower boundaries uniform distribution. default c(0,1). x2.dist string specifying distribution second assignment variable, x2. Options "normal"  "uniform". default "normal" distribution. x2.para numeric vector length 2 specifying parameters distribution second assignment variable, x2. x2.dist "normal", x2.para includes mean standard deviation normal distribution. x2.dist "uniform", x2.para includes  upper lower boundaries uniform distribution. default c(0,1). x1.cut numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined first assignment variable, x1. default 0. x2.cut numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined second assignment variable, x2. default 0. x1.fuzzy numeric vector length 2 specifying probabilities assigned control condition, terms first assignment variable, x1, individuals treatment based cutoff,  treatment individuals control condition based cutoff. sharp design, entries 0.  fuzzy design, first entry probability assigned  control individuals cutpoint, second entry  probability assigned treatment individuals cutpoint. default c(0,0), indicating sharp design. x2.fuzzy numeric vector length 2 specifying probabilities assigned control, terms second assignment variable, x2, individuals treatment based cutoff,  treatment individuals control based cutoff. sharp design, entries 0.  fuzzy design, first entry probability assigned  control individuals cutpoint, second entry  probability assigned treatment individuals cutpoint. default c(0,0), indicating sharp design. x1.design string specifying treatment option according design x1. Options "g" (treatment assigned x1 greater cutoff), "geq" (treatment assigned x1 greater equal cutoff), "l" (treatment assigned x1 less cutoff), "leq" (treatment assigned x1 less equal cutoff). x2.design string specifying treatment option according design x2. Options "g" (treatment assigned x2 greater cutoff), "geq" (treatment assigned x2 greater equal cutoff), "l" (treatment assigned x2 less cutoff), "leq" (treatment assigned x2 less equal cutoff). coeff numeric vector specifying coefficients variables linear model generate data. Coefficients following order: 1st entry intercept. 2nd entry slope treatment 1, .e. treatment effect 1. 3rd entry slope treatment 2, .e. treatment effect 2. 4th entry slope treatment, .e. treatment effect. 5th entry slope assignment 1. 6th entry slope assignment 2. 7th entry slope interaction assignment 1 assignment 2. 8th entry slope interaction treatment 1 assignment 1. 9th entry slope interaction treatment 2 assignment 1. 10th entry slope interaction treatment 1 assignment 2. 11th entry slope interaction treatment 2 assignment 2. 12th entry slope interaction treatment 1, assignment 1 assignment 2. 13th entry slope interaction treatment 2, assignment 1 assignment 2. default c(0.1, 0.5, 0.5, 1, rep(0.1, 9)). eta.sq numeric value specifying expected partial eta-squared linear model respect  treatment . used control variance noise linear model. default 0.50. alpha.list numeric vector containing significance levels (0 1) used calculate empirical alpha. default c(0.001, 0.01, anad 0.05).

title: Power Analysis of Multivariate Regression Discontinuity — mrd_power
text: mrd_power returns object class  "mrdp" containing number successful iterations,   mean, variance, power (alpha 0.001, 0.01, 0.05)   six estimators. function summary  used obtain print summary power analysis.   six estimators follows: 1st estimator, Linear, provides results linear regression estimator    combined RD using centering approach. 2nd estimator, Opt, provides results local linear regression estimator   combined RD using centering approach,    optimal bandwidth Imbens Kalyanaraman (2012) paper. 3rd estimator, Linear, provides results linear regression estimator    separate RD terms x1 using univariate approach. 4th estimator, Opt, provides results local linear regression estimator   separate RD terms x1 using univariate approach,    optimal bandwidth Imbens Kalyanaraman (2012) paper. 5th estimator, Linear, provides results linear regression estimator    separate RD terms x2 using univariate approach. 6th estimator, Opt, provides results local linear regression estimator   separate RD terms x2 using univariate approach,    optimal bandwidth Imbens Kalyanaraman (2012) paper.

title: Multiple Imputation of Regression Discontinuity Estimation — rd_impute
text: formula formula RDD; symbolic description model fitted. supplied format y ~ x simple sharp RDD y ~ x | c1 + c2 sharp RDD two covariates. fuzzy RDD may specified y ~ x + z x running variable,  z endogenous treatment variable. Covariates included  manner sharp RDD. data optional data frame containing variables model. found data, variables taken environment(formula). subset optional vector specifying subset observations used fitting process. cutpoint numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined. default 0. bw vector specifying bandwidths estimate RD.  Possible values "IK09", "IK12", user-specified non-negative numeric vector specifying bandwidths estimate RD. default "IK12". bw "IK12", bandwidth calculated using Imbens-Kalyanaraman  2012 method. bw  "IK09", bandwidth calculated using  Imbens-Kalyanaraman 2009 method. RD estimated bandwidth, half bandwidth, twice bandwidth.  single value passed function, RD similarly estimated bandwidth, half bandwidth,  twice bandwidth. kernel string indicating kernel use. Options "triangular"  (default recommended), "rectangular", "epanechnikov", "quartic",  "triweight", "tricube", "cosine". se.type specifies robust standard error calculation method use, "sandwich" package. Options , vcovHC, "HC3", "const", "HC", "HC0",  "HC1", "HC2", "HC4", "HC4m", "HC5". option  overridden cluster. cluster optional vector specifying clusters within errors assumed correlated. result reporting cluster robust SEs. option overrides anything specified se.type. suggested data discrete running  variable clustered unique value running variable (Lee Card, 2008). impute optional vector length n, indexing whole imputations. verbose logical value indicating whether print additional information  terminal. default FALSE. less Logical. TRUE, return estimates linear optimal. FALSE  return estimates linear, quadratic, cubic, optimal, half double. default FALSE. est.cov Logical. TRUE, estimates covariates included. FALSE, estimates covariates included. default FALSE. option applicable method "front". est.itt Logical. TRUE, estimates ITT returned. FALSE, estimates ITT returned. default FALSE. option applicable method "front". t.design string specifying treatment option according design. what: Power Analysis of Regression Discontinuity — rd_power
title: Power Analysis of Regression Discontinuity — rd_power
text: rd_power computes empirical probability resulting parameter estimate MRD significant, .e. empirical power (1 - beta).

title: Power Analysis of Regression Discontinuity — rd_power
code: rd_power(   num.rep = 100,   sample.size = 100,   x.dist = "normal",   x.para = c(0, 1),   x.cut = 0,   x.fuzzy = c(0, 0),   x.design = NULL,   coeff = c(0.3, 1, 0.2, 0.3),   eta.sq = 0.5,   alpha.list = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05) )

title: Power Analysis of Regression Discontinuity — rd_power
text: num.rep non-negative integer specifying number repetitions used calculate empirical power. default 100. sample.size non-negative integer specifying number observations sample. default 100. x.dist string specifying distribution assignment variable, x. Options "normal"  "uniform". default "normal" distribution. x.para numeric vector length 2 specifying parameters distribution first assignment variable, x1. x.dist "normal", x.para includes mean standard deviation normal distribution. x.dist "uniform", x.para includes  upper lower boundaries uniform distribution. default c(0,1). x.cut numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined. default 0. x.fuzzy numeric vector length 2 specifying probabilities assigned control, terms assignment variable, x, individuals treatment based cutoff,  treatment individuals control based cutoff. sharp design, entries 0.  fuzzy design, first entry probability assigned  control individuals cutpoint, second entry  probability assigned treatment individuals cutpoint. default c(0,0), indicating sharp design. x.design string specifying treatment option according design. Options "g" (treatment assigned x greater cutoff), "geq" (treatment assigned x greater equal cutoff), "l" (treatment assigned x less cutoff), "leq" (treatment assigned x less equal cutoff). coeff numeric vector specifying coefficients variables linear model generate data. Coefficients following order: 1st entry intercept. 2nd entry slope treatment, .e. treatment effect. 3rd entry slope assignment. 4th entry slope interaction treatment assignment. default c(0.3, 1, 0.2, 0.3). eta.sq numeric value specifying expected partial eta-squared linear model respect  treatment . used control variance noise linear model. default 0.50. alpha.list numeric vector containing significance levels (0 1) used calculate empirical alpha. default c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05).

title: Power Analysis of Regression Discontinuity — rd_power
text: rd_power returns object class  "rdp", including containing mean, variance, power (alpha 0.001, 0.01, 0.05)   two estimators. function summary  used obtain print summary power analysis. two estimators : 1st estimator, Linear, provides results linear regression estimator. 2nd estimator, Opt, provides results local linear regression estimator RD,         optimal bandwidth Imbens Kalyanaraman (2012) paper.

title: Power Analysis of Regression Discontinuity — rd_power
text: Imbens, G., Kalyanaraman, K. (2012).    Optimal bandwidth choice regression discontinuity estimator.    Review Economic Studies, 79(3), 933-959.   https://academic.oup.com/restud/article/79/3/933/1533189.

title: Determine Type of Regression Discontinuity Design — rd_type

title: Determine Type of Regression Discontinuity Design — rd_type
text: data data.frame, row representing observation. treat string specifying name numeric treatment variable (treated = positive values). assign_1 string specifying variable name primary assignment. cutoff_1 numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined, primary assignment. operator_1 operator specifying treatment option according design primary assignment. Options   "g" (treatment assigned x1 greater cutoff), "geq" (treatment assigned x1 greater equal cutoff), "l" (treatment assigned x1 less cutoff), "leq" (treatment assigned x1 less equal cutoff). assign_2 optional string specifying variable name secondary assignment. cutoff_2 optional numeric value containing cutpoint assignment treatment determined, secondary assignment. operator_2 operator specifying treatment option according design secondary assignment. Options    "g" (treatment assigned x2 greater cutoff),  "geq" (treatment assigned x2 greater equal cutoff),  "l" (treatment assigned x2 less cutoff),  "leq" (treatment assigned x2 less equal cutoff).

title: Determine Type of Regression Discontinuity Design — rd_type
text: rd_type returns list two elements: crosstab cross-table data.frame. Columns dataframe include   treatment rules, number observations control condition,   number observations treatment condition, probability   observation treatment control. type string specifying type design used, either "SHARP" "FUZZY".

title: Determine Type of Regression Discontinuity Design — rd_type
code: set.seed(12345) x <- runif(1000, -1, 1) cov <- rnorm(1000) y <- 3 + 2 * x + 3 * cov + 10 * (x >= 0) + rnorm(1000) df <- data.frame(cbind(y, x, t = x>=0)) rddapp:::rd_type(df, 't', 'x', 0, 'geq') #> $crosstab #>    A1 Control Treat Prob. #> 1 < 0     469     0     0 #> 2 = 0       0   531     1 #>  #> $type #> [1] "SHARP" #>

title: Plot the Simulated Estimates for Sensitivity Analyses — sens_plot
code: sens_plot(   sim_results,   level = 0.95,   x = c("A1", "A2", "bw"),   plot_models = unique(sim_results$model),   yrange = NULL )

title: Plot the Simulated Estimates for Sensitivity Analyses — sens_plot
text: sim_results data.frame returned rd_sens_cutoff, rd_sens_bw, mrd_sens_cutoff, mrd_sens_bw. level numeric value 0 1 specifying confidence level CIs (assuming normal sampling distribution). default 0.95. x string column name varying parameter sim_results.  used x-axis plot. Possible values c("A1", "A2", "bw"),  column names sim_results.  A1 specifies varying cutoffs assignment 1 A2 specifies assignment 2. bw indicates varying parameter bandwidth. plot_models character vector specifying models plotted (.e. models estimated  different approaches). Possible values unique(sim_results$model)). yrange optional numeric vector specifying range y-axis.

title: Plot the Simulated Estimates for Sensitivity Analyses — sens_plot
code: set.seed(12345) x <- runif(1000, -1, 1) cov <- rnorm(1000) y <- 3 + 2 * x + 3 * cov + 10 * (x >= 0) + rnorm(1000) m <- rd_est(y ~ x | cov, t.design = "geq") sim_cutoff <- rd_sens_cutoff(m, seq(-.5, .5, length.out = 10)) sens_plot(sim_cutoff, x = "A1", plot_models = c("linear", "optimal"))  sim_bw <- rd_sens_bw(m, seq(.1, 1, length.out = 10)) sens_plot(sim_bw, x = "bw")
